displayed_text: Patient: Yeah, yeah. I will. Doctor: You could do it the same day, but then we don’t – Patient: No, I will. Doctor: But I just have to tell you about aliens, and I’ve got nothing else to talk to you about. Patient: Well, yeah, I know. I’ll get my daughter over here. (Laughs) Doctor: Okay. Patient: The nurse, his nurse is mailing me the paper forms, but I will, I’m just going to tell M_ when I walk up in here. Because then it shows right up in my record; you guys have it in a day or two. Doctor: Yep. Patient: I don’t have to deal with one extra fax. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And all that. Doctor: So, April seventeenth for me and then come in any time before that for PSA.

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: -that's not what we want. Patient: Do I throw away? Doctor: No, no no no. Don't go throw anything. We'll take your leftovers, but at the moment just keep it in case we need to come back to it this year. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Don't, don't do anything. Family Member: Okay. Patient: What about the finasteride I'm still on? Doctor: That's okay. Because you've been taking that for your pee and you’re just being- Patient: I don’t know what’s the other one. Family Member: So okay. Patient: Finasteride and folic acid, we're the only other ones I was taking. Family Member: There's no reason why you can't you take calcium with vitamin nuts.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: The good thing about that in addition to the survival is you have pain relief with that. So, actually if you didn’t have any pain, I couldn’t get that cleared through insurance because they only want people who have discomfort and pain. I’m not saying you have to be writhing on the floor Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: but you have to sort of say oh, yeah, I get pain so, you know, I know I have cancer. Um, but you’re actually a good candidate for that. You’re otherwise all your blood counts and everything is also good because if you were already coming in here with low white cells or low red cells you wouldn’t be great but you don’t have that problem. So, Patient: Okay. Doctor: maybe the next step should be this medicine called Xofigo which, you know, we can have a side effects sheet given to you. We have to run it through insurance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That might take a minute. Patient: Okay. Family Member: In addition to the radium or that? Doctor: No, that is the radium. Patient: Oh, that is the radium. Doctor: Yeah. So, there’s different names.

Family Member: So you can radiate? Doctor: We can radiate anywhere. Family Member: So in C___ Dr. F____ can radiate. Doctor: Dr. F____ can radiate it. If it’s needed. Now, he won't just willy nilly do it unless you have pain, or we've shown that everything about you is stable and those are the only two areas that’s acting up. Family Member: Well, that’s good to know that. I didn’t know that. Doctor: Yeah see you’re not just out there. Patient: Now I’ve got a question for you. Doctor: Yeah. Shoot. Patient: Nobody really explained to me what I will feel as this disease progresses- Doctor: Mmm. Patient: -as it changes and that I will detect the symptoms that I will. Doctor: Yeah. Well, the sheer fact that you are actually asking me that tells me that you don't have many symptoms, because people who have the symptoms, be it bone pain or just extreme fatigue or weight Loss, no appetite will tell me, “Oh man, look at all these things happening to me is because of my cancer?” So when you're curious, that means like, okay, none of this stuff is happening, which is great, but you worry about it because you think this is it, I'm gonna get bone pain. And this is it. You know, that's not the case. If you have pain in the bone, there are medicines to help or more importantly, there are techniques like radiation to help and there are other medicines that we can do to and other strategies to help the pain go away. So pain is usually what everybody worries about is number one, and then the other ones would be things like, you know, complete quality of life loss is, “I don't want to anything”

Patient: So uh hum, okay, okay. Doctor: It’s not going to drop by like ninety-nine percent. So don’t expect; with hormone therapy, that’s what usually happens - Patient: Yeah I got it. Doctor: - You get a dramatic drop. When you get a drop because cancer is dying. With this, if this was truly the only lymph node. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know then you would expect the PSA to drop by like ninety percent. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: You know if this is one of five lymph nodes, and you know the other four are invisible, then you drop by twenty percent. Family Member: If it drops by twenty percent, then we’ll know okay somewhere else - Doctor: cancer; we’ll look at the majority of the cancer where eighty percent went somewhere else. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: In the meantime you’ve bought a few months, maybe a year, of not starting hormone therapy.

Patient: What kind of pills? Doctor: So these are FDA-approved pills called Xtandi, which is the trade name. Uh, they’re four pills once a day, and their primary goal of how they work is it’s, it’s like a big hormone pill again. So it’s to help your shot work better. It also is approved by the FDA because it helps you live longer. No cures. Same as we were before but we need to get a handle on all these things in the lung. In the same way, you’re also a candidate for chemo to tell you the truth. Uh, so chemo’s in the mix as well, but the majority of folks I think, and I’m not saying you do, but my patients tend to prefer pills before going on to chemotherapy, and I think way back when we initially again reconnected you were not in so much favor of chemo, uh, as he’s already shaking his head, but I want to bring that up again because at some point we may need to go to chemo. So I want to put that out there still. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but we do have a set of pills. Now, the good news is every time there’s an approved medication, you know, we’re at K______, so we do a lot of clinical studies. So one of our studies is to use that same medication and see if we add a second pill to half the group whether you’d respond better. So I like that study because it’s all pills and no one gets a placebo when you’re thinking about the Xtandi pills. Everyone is on the regular pill that is approved. The question of the placebo versus the other drug is extra. Okay? So I’m not sure if that makes sense or if you’ve got questions with that, but we’re going to try hard to have you be, you know, considered for that study. Uh, I want you to still recover well from your, your hospitalization, but, uh, but that’s in the works for us to consider. The other part is either way, however we move forward, there’s another study, which is a registry study, called, Iron Man. Uh, not that you become iron man- Patient: Hum. Doctor: but that all your experiences as to what’s happened to you get captured. And that means you write out and answer questionnaires. I write out and answer questionnaires. Uh, and then about once a year we take some blood to see what’s happening uh in terms of new research. Uh, and that participation’s pretty cool because a lot of other men around the world are, are participating. And so we get answers from guys from Australia, Ireland, uh, you know, England uh, gosh, Canada, France, so all of that. So everyone’s experience will be captured. And they’re all like you, in the same boat. So we hope you consider that as well. Uh, but I think what we might do is workup to make sure that you’re eligible for all that stuff. I want to introduce you to M___, who’s our research nurse, uh, who just wants to say hi, and then I think we’ll have you come back in a couple weeks when you feel like you’re a little bit stronger. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: How, how long have you been home now? Patient: Two days or- Family Member: Three days. Doctor: From S___’s. Yes. So I, I need you to be two weeks, walking around, not back in the hospital, fully recovered- Patient: Um hum.

Family Member: Like we really want to be treating this aggressively. Doctor: Well, I think if I was going to choose between those two things, and I had the means to choose between the two, I would choose the PSMA. Patient: Yes, I know. Doctor: Yeah. I mean this is really just antidotal for me for two patients. They’ve got other things in between that could have nothing to do with testosterone. We’re, we’re trying to make as much, we’ve got somebody interested in a small trial to test the idea, but I, I really, I wouldn’t be that confident. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Like you said, geez, which has the better chance? Family Member: No. I would still be doing the Germany thing, I just- Doctor: I mean I think we’ll do that uh you know really quickly if that’s what you wanted to do. So I can work on that this week. Patient: Yeah. I appreciate that. Doctor: To find out - I’ll also see what I can find out about this test I mentioned then. Patient: Oh for the marker? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll just give us some information about uh uh you know we’ve learned that folks who have that marker, the cancer tends to be way more aggressive in addition to being less sensitive a hormone treatment, there may also be a marker, a change in the cancer that’s made it more aggressive. Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah, I saw that. Doctor: Today’s is not bad. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It might be an opportunity to put on a second drug on top of this current drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you would stay on this, but we would pile on something else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, M___’s lookin’ to see. We have about two trials to consider. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But one of them, I just gotta make sure. The one that I am thinking of, I have to make sure that there is an opening. You know how the drill goes. Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: But the good news is the scans were just done. It really does not show. Patient: That’s good.

Patient: It’ll go back someday. Doctor: Mm. Patient: Yeah, so. Doctor: Anywho! Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay, here's where we are. Your PSA is six something- Patient: Yeah. Doctor: -and it was two something before. So with that rise, I got a little worried. Because I don't want the Xtandi to get away from us. At that point, there was a study and there still is, where people on Xtandi if they start to do this with their PSA, might be eligible to add another pill right on to that. So you still stay on Xtandi. But this other pill might make the Xtandi sort of work better. And, you know, if you were on full dose, you'd be eligible, if you were on three pills, as well as just the two pills a day is still an option. So initially, we weren't sure if it was going to open because this was a study that had a sugar pill arm that I wasn't too keen on. But with this new, kind of like update, everybody gets the pill. So this is where the study is. So here you are in your Xtandi. Xtandi, Xtandi, Xtandi. And then you get randomized. So flip of a coin to either get this new medicine at a certain dose, or this new medicine at the same dose. Okay, so so far, both arms are the same, you just get a new medicine at the same dose, okay, no placebo. This arm is going to keep you like that, so you take the Xtandi plus the new pill at the new dose, no problem, you're just on that. This arm is you on Xtandi plus the new pill, but every month, they're going to try to increase that dose gently. So you get another pill that has more milligrams in it. While that's happening, if you were on this arm, you get a matching placebo. So you do get a sugar pill, but that's in addition to the new pill already being on board. You still with me? Patient: No, you gotta slow down. Doctor: Okay. Do you want me to say it again? Patient: Try me again. Doctor: Okay, no worries. Okay, here's you. Patient: Yeah.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Family Member: Last time you said they were absolutely the same. One hundred perc- (nervous laugh) Doctor: So I still think they are because, but what this says is that there is increasing uptake. So since I’m gonna give you these… Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: …I wanted you to know. Unfortunately the size are the how bright it is. So increasing uptake means it’s brighter now than it was before. Patient: This is in the bones? Doctor: Correct, yeah. That grade of brightness I guess, doesn’t mean a whole lot for prostate cancer on the bone scan. Okay because even healing bone can look brighter than the other. So on the bone scan really what would tell me that there is progression of the disease would be if there were new areas and there were not. Okay? But I just needed to explain this because- Family Member: Yes. Patient: -- of this is what the scan report is gonna read which I’m gonna give you right now. So this – but the same areas were the lower back and the left hip, the hip bones, so those are the two main areas. Family Member: And the rib or not the rib? Doctor: The ribs are still there and we are following it. It’s in the left side on the sixth rib. Yeah I mean that also was there before Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: and that stayed about the same. Family Member: But the increased uptake is in the lower back and the left hip?

Patient: Yeah well I had the flu and it was pneumonia the same time about three years ago. Doctor: Umm. I don’t know if that’s what it is, but guess what. I’m gonna send you to this good doctor. Dr. S____. He’s right in this clinic also and he’s gonna check you out. He’s probably gonna um make some recommendations about what to do for us to figure this out. But I think that’s important too. Now the good part is you’re already getting the shots. Patient: Um hmmm. Doctor: And you know your PSA was coming down just from doing that. That part’s great but I don’t want to miss all the little details. I want to be right on top of this. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: I feel great. Doctor: I was going to say, you look great. I know this is you know waah why can’t we just get this done. But I don’t want to miss anything for you. Patient: Ahhh no I feel great. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I have no problems… Doctor: That’s awesome.

Family Member: Just you? Oh wow. Doctor: And, if you want to know more, I mean, we can also have you, an appointment with one of our genetic counselors. Patient: Well, you, you gave me a card with your other e-mail. Doctor: Yes. Patient: Not – so I still have that. Doctor: Yeah, so if anybody, you know, has questions about it and wants more information. You know, I’m not a genetic counselor, but I can at least tell them what I just told you Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And kind of try to, and then I’m going to find out probably today or tomorrow what this color test --- Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I don’t get anything from this test. It’s just an easy one to do. Family Member: Yeah, you know what MTHFR is? Do you know is that related to this? Because our daughter has that. Doctor: I don’t know what that means.

Patient: No, no, not right now we don’t. Doctor: So if you want to come off then you should probably make an appointment with him. Okay because ah - regardless if the PSA is going up or if the scan is you know not even changing. If you want to come off study Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: then yeah it might be a good idea to make that so we sort of connect with him. Okay? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Does that sound good? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Any other questions? Patient: No. Like I say the PSA thing is, of course you know we were always brought up with that kind of… Doctor: I know, I know. Patient: And you understand it. Doctor: No I absolutely… Patient: And I just wondered you know with.

Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Alright. So today we’ll go ahead and I know you gave G____ the list of medications… Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Your blood pressure and stuff, we’ll send those in. Patient: Okay. Because I said my vitamins, that’s what, that boosts me up. Because like when I’m fatigued I can’t get up, I take one of those vitamins. Doctor: That helps. Patient: And I’m off and running. Yes sir. I’m off running man. Doctor: Now are you still taking prednisone?

Family Member: Oh, yes, beautiful. That’s what we said. Everybody always talks about Johannesburg because it kind of reminded you of New York City. And nobody never said anything about Cape Town, and it’s just beautiful, the beaches and everything, like, wow. Doctor: Because they were having a drought there for a long time. Family Member: Yeah. In certain areas, it still is, like the parks, they don’t, they have like, use the, uh, sanitary lotion and stuff on your hands and toilets don’t flush. Doctor: So when you were like in Cape Town. What did you guys do when you were there? Because it’s like summer there now, isn’t it? Family Member: Yeah. It getting to be summer there. Yeah. The weather was very nice. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Did you like go to the beach or you just-? Patient: No. Family Member: Yeah. We did go to the beach one day. Patient: We went to the beach but we didn’t get in it. Family Member: It was the Indian Beach. Patient: Yeah. We didn’t get in. Doctor: What’s the Indian Beach?
